name: Bjarnarflag
description:
Bjarnarflag is an active geothermal area located in North Iceland, near Lake Mývatn in one of the country's most volcanically active regions. This site features numerous fumaroles, steam vents, and bubbling mud pools that demonstrate the intense geothermal activity beneath the Earth's surface. The area has been harnessed for energy production since 1969, when Iceland's first geothermal power station was built here. The Bjarnarflag Geothermal Power Station continues to operate today, producing electricity and providing hot water for the surrounding communities, making it both a natural wonder and an important industrial site.

Visitors to Bjarnarflag can observe the raw power of geothermal energy through various surface manifestations. Bright yellow and orange sulfur deposits paint the ground around steam vents, creating an otherworldly landscape. The constant hissing of escaping steam and the distinctive smell of hydrogen sulfide (similar to rotten eggs) create a unique sensory experience. The geothermal field demonstrates temperatures reaching up to 200-250°C just below the surface. Warning signs are posted throughout the area, as the ground can be unstable and scalding hot in places. Visitors must stay on marked paths for safety.

The site is easily accessible from Route 1 (Ring Road), located just a few kilometers east of Reykjahlíð village. A parking area allows visitors to safely stop and explore the geothermal features. The area offers excellent photography opportunities, particularly in winter when steam plumes create dramatic contrasts against the snow-covered landscape. Nearby attractions include the Mývatn Nature Baths (3 km), Námaskarð geothermal area (1 km), and Hverir mud pools. The site is accessible year-round, though winter visitors should exercise caution on potentially icy walkways. Visiting Bjarnarflag typically takes 15-30 minutes, and it can easily be combined with other Mývatn area attractions for a comprehensive geothermal experience.
opening_hours: Open 24/7 (viewable from road, stay on marked paths)
